processed_by.processor: Cui, Hong using Text2XML java application init commit r86, validated against beeSchema.xsd revision f0a80a8516a06e51224d01314403eb26d60f881d

taxon_identification.taxon_hierarchy: family rosaceae;tribe rubeae;genus rubus;subgenus eubatus;section hispidi;

key_statement.statement: Leaves of primocane coriaceous and lustrous (when fresh), dark green or purple-or bronze-tinged, evergreen, or nearly so (at least strongly marcescent).

Primocanes soon closely prostrate, 1-5 mm. in diameter, covered by few (or no) to very numerous slender bristles and glands; primocane-leaflets 3 (rarely 5), not prickly beneath; terminal leaflet obovate to rhombic-ovate, blunt-toothed; axis of inflorescence without long bristles; wide-ranging continental species

Primocanes arching, soon depressed and vigorously forking, stout, covered with very many hard subulate prickles 3-4.5 mm. long, as well as some glands and bristles; primocane-leaflets with hooked prickles on midrib beneath, 3 or 5; terminal leaflet obovate, elliptic or ovate, sharper-toothed; axis of inflorescence and pedicels prickly; northeastern coastwise species
Leaves of primocanes membranaceous to subcoriaceous, opaque or nearly so, dark to pale green, sharply toothed or dentate2.
Leaflets of upper floricane-leaves broadly rounded or obtuse at apex3.
Primocane-leaflets blunt or merely abruptly short-pointed4.
Inflorescence a corymb or irregular cyme borne well above the leaves of the flowering shoots; leaflets sharp-serrate5.
Pedicels glandless.
Primocane-leaflets mostly 5; southeastern.
Leaves submembranaceous, glabrous or promptly glabrate on both surfaces; primocanes with some stipitate glands among the longer bristles and prickles
Leaves subcoriaceous, permanently pilose on both surfaces; primocanes glandless
Primocane-leaflets mostly 3; canes and pedicels glandless; mid-western
Pedicels copiously glandular; primocane-leaflets 3 or 5; northern
Inflorescence a leafy-bracted interrupted raceme, its strongly glandular and bristly pedicels overtopped by the 3-foliolate and simple bracteal leaves; leaflets dentate; â€œWest Virginian
Primocane-leaflets tapering to acute or acuminate tip.
Primocane-leaves 3-foliolate, pubescent beneath, merely acute, 2-3.5 cm. long, broadly ovate; most pedicels subtended by attenuate bracts barely 1 mm. broad; West Virginian

Primo cane-leaves 3-or 5-foliolate; leaflets glabrous, long-acuminate, mostly 5.5-8 cm. long, ovate-lanceolate or narrowly obovate; most pedicels subtended by elliptic or oblong bracts 2-5 mm. broad; species of Vt
Leaflets of upper floricane-leaves gradually tapering to acute or acutish tips6.
Primocane-leaflets abruptly short-tipped7.
Terminal leaflet of 3-foliolate bracteal leaves about half as broad as long.
Leaves glabrous beneath except along nerves, subcoriaceous; northeastern
Leaves pubescent beneath, membranaceous; mid-western.
Primocane-leaflets gradually rounded or tapering at base, sharply double-serrate; canes and petioles essentially glandless
Primocane-leaflets cordate or subcordate, blunt-serrate; canes and petioles copiously stipitate-glandular
Terminal leaflet of 3-foliolate bracteal leaves nearly as broad as long, firm.
Canes glandless; primocane-leaflets 5 (or 3); plant of n. Wisc
Canes copiously stipitate-glandular; primocane leaflets 3; plant of montane W. Va
Primocane-leaflets gradually tapering to acute or acuminate tips8.
Leaves glabrous or merely pilose on nerves beneath9.
Leaflets jagged or lacerate-toothed, with many sinuses 3-5 mm. deep; ribs deeply impressed above; calyx glandular; local in se. Vt
Leaflets regularly serrate, double-serrate or serrate-dentate, the sinuses mostly 1-3 mm. deep10.
Canes remotely prickly or bristly, the surface of the cane clearly evident between the bristles; petioles smooth to sparsely prickly11.
Terminal primocane-leaflet merely acute, not long-acuminate; leaflets usually only 3; plant of n. Mich
Terminal primocane-leaflet acuminate or caudate-tipped.
Primocane glandless or only exceptionally gland-bearing, from, nearly prickleless to prickly, the coarsest prickles merely subulate-setiform
Primocane copiously glandular.
Canes (especially primocanes) merely bristly and glandular, 2.5-3.5 mm. in diameter; leaves pale green, thin, dull, with deeply impressed ribs
Canes with many broadish-based hard subulate-conic prickles, stout, 3-7 mm. thick; leaves dark green, glossy, the ribs not impressed
Canes very densely hirsute or bristly, the surface obscured; petioles of primo cane-leaves densely clothed12.
Primocane-leaves 5 (sometimes 3)-foliolate; pedicels copiously setiferous; northeastern.
Leaflets of both primocane and floricane only one-half to one-third as broad as long, caudate-tipped; inflorescence a slender raceme, its lower foliaceous bracts all simple
Leaflets broader, rarely less than half as broad as long, acute or acuminate, scarcely caudate; inflorescence a simple to much-branched corymb with lower bracts 3-foliolate
Primocane-leaves 3-foliolate; West Virginian.
Canes slender, about 2 mm. thick; petioles glandless; axis of inflorescence and pedicels with remote short prickles
Canes stout, 7-8 mm. thick; petioles glandular; axis of inflorescence and pedicels copiously long-bristly
Leaves soft-pubescent or velvety to touch beneath13.
Canes copiously glandular amongst the bristles.
Petiolule of terminal primocane-leaflet only 4 or 5 mm. long; rachis of inflorescence and pedicels with long spicules; plant of ne. N. Y
Petiolule of terminal primocane-leaflet 1.5-3.3 cm. long; rachis of inflorescence minutely stipitate-glandular or short-setulose.
Terminal primocane-leaflet on a petiolule 2-3.3 cm. long, the median petiolules (of 5-foliolate leaves) 0.6-2 cm. long; longer leaflets of flowering shoots 5-7 cm. long; plant of se. Mass

Terminal primocane-leaflet on a petiolule 1.5-2 cm. long, the median petiolule (of 5-foliolate leaves) 6-8 mm. long; longer leaflets of flowering shoots 3-4 cm. long; plant of centr, N. Y. 82. R. furtivus.
Canes glandless; petiolule of terminal primocane-leaflet 1 cm. long; pedicels minutely glandular; plant of interior N. B
